properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Lake Superior possible on Monday. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop Monday morning as winds shift to a southwesterly direction. These snow squalls are then expected to continue into Monday night. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours are possible Monday and Monday night. Dangerous winter driving conditions will be possible Monday. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T12:49:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T20:50:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1466069329.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today and tonight. Flurries, heavy at times, will continue off of Lake Superior today and tonight. Snow squalls are forecast to move back into the area Monday morning. Snowfall amounts of 5 cm per 12 hours are likely with some localized areas getting up to 10 cm. Dangerous winter driving conditions in bursts of heavy snow and blowing snow will continue into Monday. Motorists are advised to adjust travel plans accordingly. Note that a snow squall watch has been issued for intensifying snow squalls Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T12:49:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T20:50:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3399630376.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values between minus 40 and minus 55 continue. This prolonged cold snap is expected to persist through the coming week for many areas of Alberta. There will be some moderation in temperature at times, typically during daylight hours. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T09:28:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T17:29:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0715549910.2021

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 km/h. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Monday morning through Monday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Monday morning, and become heavy, at times, by midday. Moderate northwesterly winds in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in reduced visibility in blowing snow over some areas, especially Monday night. The snow and strong northwesterly winds are expected to persist throughout Monday night and possibly into Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-08T11:36:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T19:37:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3705881804.2021
Area: Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values between minus 45 and minus 55 continue. This prolonged cold snap is expected to persist through much of the coming week for many areas of northern Saskatchewan. There will be some moderation in temperature at times, typically during daylight hours. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Georgian Bay possible tonight. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop late this afternoon or this evening as strong west to northwest winds become established. These snow squalls are then expected to continue into tonight before weakening on Monday. Snowfall amounts in the 10 to 20 cm range appear possible tonight. Dangerous winter driving conditions will be possible tonight. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. The lake effect snow will move to the north of the region by Monday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T11:06:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T19:07:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3869625184.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Georgian Bay beginning this afternoon. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop once again this afternoon as strong west to northwest winds become established. These snow squalls are then expected to continue into tonight before weakening on Monday. At this point in time, very heavy snowfall amounts in the 15 to 40 cm range appear possible, with the heaviest amounts likely in the Midland to Orillia to Port Carling areas. Winds will whip up the freshly fallen snow resulting in sudden near zero visibility in blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions are possible this afternoon and tonight. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. The lake effect snow will move to the north of the region by Monday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T08:20:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T16:21:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0316994867.2021
Area: Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Turning cold with Arctic air moving throughout BC Following a relatively mild first half of winter, a transition to much colder conditions will begin throughout BC. Cold Arctic air is currently pushing southwards across the BC Interior, and towards the BC coast through the remainder of the weekend. The cold air will be in place throughout the province by Monday, and persist for the remainder of the week. Temperatures over Interior regions will be 10 to 20 degrees below the seasonal average, while coastal areas will be 5 to 10 degrees below seasonal, making for the coldest conditions seen this season. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T09:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-07T18:00:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2631546824.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Georgian Bay continue tonight. Additional snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are possible by Monday morning. Dangerous winter driving conditions are expected tonight, particularly along parts of highway 400 between Waubaushene and Parry Sound and highway 11 between Orillia and Bracebridge. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. The lake effect snow will move to the north of the region by Monday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wave heights: 6 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: south-facing shorelines on the Burin and southern Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: Monday evening through Tuesday evening. Remarks: A passing storm will produce long period swells, with large breaking waves approaching the coast. Stay a safe distance away from the shoreline due to the rapid approach of large waves. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Turning cold with Arctic air moving throughout BC Following a relatively mild first half of winter, a transition to much colder conditions will begin throughout BC. Cold Arctic air is currently pushing southwards across the BC Interior, and towards the BC coast through the remainder of the weekend. The cold air will be in place throughout the province by Monday, and persist for the remainder of the week. Temperatures over Interior regions will be 10 to 20 degrees below the seasonal average, while coastal areas will be 5 to 10 degrees below seasonal, making for the coldest conditions seen this season. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T09:59:35-00:00

Snow may ease this evening and then reintensify tonight. Snow is forecast to end Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

For Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, expect additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm before the snow tapers off to a few flurries Monday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill values near minus 45 will occur tonight into Monday morning courtesy of bitterly cold temperatures and brisk westerly winds. There will be some improvement Monday afternoon as temperatures inch upward a little. However the bitterly cold Arctic air will remain entrenched over far northwestern Ontario through the remainder of the week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h except near 90 km/h along parts of the Atlantic coast. Locations: all of Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning late this afternoon for western Nova Scotia. Beginning this evening elsewhere. Snow ending from west to east Monday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will continue to spread across Nova Scotia this evening. Strong northeasterly winds will develop this evening and persist into Monday morning giving near-zero visibilities at times in blowing and drifting snow. Snow will gradually end from west to east across the province beginning early Monday morning but strong northerly winds will continue to give blowing snow over the eastern half of the province until Monday afternoon. Additionally, higher than normal water levels are expected to occur near high tide early Monday morning along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia with this storm. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 35 cm, with the highest accumulations expected over the Connaigre and Burin peninsulas and in the Clarenville and Terra Nova areas. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 to 100 km/h becoming northwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Monday morning through Monday night. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop Monday morning. The snow will combine with strong northeasterly winds Monday morning and strong northwesterly winds Monday afternoon and evening to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Over the Avalon, the snow will become mixed with ice pellets later in the morning and and is expected to change to rain or drizzle over some areas in the afternoon. Conditions will improve Monday night for areas along the South Coast. Strong northwesterly winds and periods of snow will persist over more northern areas, including the St. John's Metro area, throughout Monday night and possibly into Tuesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together.
